s.text: Saying that taxes would be lower if taxes were lower is true, but not edifying.
But if we thought of it as a "sight penalty" and calculated it as the added tax a person pays now for the privilege of being able to see, it works out to something like $208 per sighted taxpayer.
(Click if you're interested in another marriage penalty on the working poor that no one seems upset about.)
(Click if you're interested in another marriage penalty on the working poor that no one seems upset about.)
But now many in Congress are making a great cause of one particular differential: the one between married and unmarried couples.
If two partners earn $40,000 each, a decision to get married could, on its face, cost them more than $1,000.
